fa92dbf68a4d779204a8f09d9af0b7ff (21:09): anilruby1: chatting
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (21:09): anilruby1: google for vim cheatsheet
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (21:09): to answer questions that aren't answerable by a trivial google?
299813521c8e0cb0572b9feea44f57d2 (21:09): groken: if the lines are likely to be split, then you need to do this in Perl.  The same principles apply but that scripting language is more flexible.
299813521c8e0cb0572b9feea44f57d2 (21:10): anilruby1: start with this. It's short. http://www.phaget4.org/seidel/vi.html
6b226aaac03cc8f24b42b4eae2dc7a2b (21:10): ic56, what if i strip all new lines?

fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (21:10): ic56: it's do-able in vim (and possibly sed), but you're right -- it would be easier in Perl. Perl's memory requirements won't be drastically different from vim's though.
6b226aaac03cc8f24b42b4eae2dc7a2b (21:10): Zathrus, memory is not an issue. this is a one time parse
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (21:11): groken: oh, you really don't want to do that... a lot of tools will die horribly on single lines that long.
6b226aaac03cc8f24b42b4eae2dc7a2b (21:12): this is a single record: http://rafb.net/paste/results/4VAHKx13.html

299813521c8e0cb0572b9feea44f57d2 (21:12): groken: you'd have to strip *some* newlines, not all.  If you can get the document to have one newline for each <p>...</p> then the rest is easy in vi or sed.

299813521c8e0cb0572b9feea44f57d2 (21:16): groken: Wow.  Unless you are guaranteed that "DEEP" will be present at the beginning of every record, then you requires a context sensitive parser.  I.e. sed/vim *really* aren't the right tools for the job.

6b226aaac03cc8f24b42b4eae2dc7a2b (21:45): can you explain what in that cmd stores text in \1
6b226aaac03cc8f24b42b4eae2dc7a2b (21:45): ?
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (21:45): besides, I learned some more about vim's godawful regex syntax in the process :)
6b226aaac03cc8f24b42b4eae2dc7a2b (21:45): lol
299813521c8e0cb0572b9feea44f57d2 (21:45): groken: the \( ... \) stores
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (21:46): it stores the name of the "tag" in \1 (that's the \([^:]\+\) part)
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (21:47): it stores the "data" in \2 (the \(\_.\{-}\) part... kinda; the </p[^>]*> modifies that capture)
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (21:48): so it matches everything between pairs of <p and </p> and rewrites it as <tag>data</tag>
